translated: The Guide
The Reversal Section
The Analysis
The Analysis of the Fourfold Guide
Herein, what is the fourfold guide?
“The unexpounded purport”: this is it.

original: Byañjanena suttassa neruttañca adhippāyo ca nidānañca pubbāparasandhi ca gavesitabbo.
analyzed: byañjanena suttassa neruttañca adhippāyaḥ ca nidānañca pubba apara sandhi ca gavesitabbaḥ
translated: The unexpounded and the purport should be sought in the Thread by means of the phrasing, the source, and the sequence of the terms.

original: Tattha katamaṁ neruttaṁ, yā niruttipadasaṁhitā, yaṁ dhammānaṁ nāmaso ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: tattha katamam yā nirutti pada sahitāḥ yam dhammānam
translated: Herein, what is the unexpounded? It is the name-group and the phrasing-group.

original: Yadā hi bhikkhu atthassa ca nāmaṁ jānāti, dhammassa ca nāmaṁ jānāti, tathā tathā naṁ abhiniropeti.
analyzed: yadā hi bhikkhu atthassa ca nāmam jānāti dhammassa ca nāmam jānāti tathā tathā nam abhiniropeti
translated: For when a bhikkhu knows the name and knows the phrasing of ideas, he can then construe them thus and thus.

original: Ayañca vuccati atthakusalo dhammakusalo byañjanakusalo niruttikusalo pubbāparakusalo
analyzed: ayam ca vuccati attha kusalaḥ dhamma kusalaḥ byañjana kusalaḥ nirutti kusalaḥ pubba apara kusalaḥ
translated: And this is called “skilled in the meaning, skilled in the phrasing, skilled in the name, skilled in the source, skilled in the sequence,

analyzed: desanā kusalaḥ atīta adhivacana kusalaḥ anāgata adhivacana kusalaḥ paccuppanna adhivacana kusalaḥ
translated: skilled in teaching, skilled in the past designation, skilled in the future designation, skilled in the present designation,

analyzed: itthā adhivacana kusalaḥ purisa adhivacana kusalaḥ napusaka adhivacana kusalaḥ eka adhivacana kusalaḥ
translated: skilled in the designation of a woman, skilled in the designation of a man, skilled in the designation of a neuter, skilled in the designation of one,

original: anekādhivacanakusalo, evaṁ sabbāni kātabbāni janapadaniruttāni sabbā ca janapadaniruttiyo.
analyzed: aneka adhivacana kusalaḥ evam sabbāni kātabbāni janapada niruttāni sabbā ca janapada niruttiyaḥ
translated: He is skilled in the many terms for this, and so he should do all the local expressions and all the local terms.
This is the section on terms.
Herein, what is the purport?
“The Dhamma protects one who lives by the Dhamma
Like a great parasol in the rainy season.
This is the advantage in the Dhamma being well-practised:

analyzed: na duggatim gacchati dhamma cārī iti
translated: The one who lives by the Dhamma does not go to a bad destination.”
What is the Blessed One’s purport here?

original: Ye apāyehi parimuccitukāmā bhavissanti, te dhammacārino bhavissantīti ayaṁ ettha bhagavato adhippāyo.
analyzed: ye apāyehi parimuccitu kāmāḥ bhavissanti te dhamma cārinaḥ bhavissanti iti ayam ettha bhagavataḥ adhippāyaḥ
translated: Those who will wish to be freed from the states of deprivation will live by the Dhamma. This is the Blessed One’s purport here.
“A thief caught at the place of breaking in
Is killed and destroyed by his own action.
So after death in the next world

analyzed: sa kammunā haññati bajjhate ca ati
translated: This generation is killed and destroyed by its own action.”
What is the Blessed One’s purport here?

original: Sañcetanikānaṁ katānaṁ kammānaṁ upacitānaṁ dukkhavedanīyānaṁ aniṭṭhaṁ asātaṁ vipākaṁ paccanubhavissatīti ayaṁ ettha bhagavato adhippāyo.
analyzed: sañcetanikānam katānam kammānam upacitānam dukkha vedanīyānam aniṭṭham asātam vipākam paccanubhavissati iti ayam ettha bhagavataḥ adhippāyaḥ
translated: He will experience the painful, disagreeable result of his intentional, accumulated kamma. This is the Blessed One’s purport here.
“Those who, desiring happiness for beings,
Harm them with a rod,
Seeking their own happiness,
After death do not obtain happiness.”
What is the Blessed One’s intention here?

original: Ye sukhena atthikā bhavissanti, te pāpakammaṁ na karissantīti ayaṁ ettha bhagavato adhippāyo.
analyzed: ye sukhena atthikāḥ bhavissanti te pāpa kammam na karissanti iti ayam ettha bhagavataḥ adhippāyaḥ
translated: His intention is this: Those who will desire happiness will not do evil deeds.

analyzed: middhī yadā hoti mahat hasaḥ ca
translated: “When one is drowsy and over-eats,
And sleeps, rolling around at will,
Like a great pig who has found a trough,
The fool again and again enters a womb.”
What is the Blessed One’s intention here?

original: Ye jarāmaraṇena aṭṭiyitukāmā bhavissanti, te bhavissanti bhojane mattaññuno indriyesu
analyzed: ye jarā maraṇena aṭṭiyitu kāmāḥ bhavissanti te bhavissanti bhojane mattaññunaḥ indriyesu
translated: His intention is this: Those who will desire to be disgusted with aging and death will be moderate in eating,🔽will guard the doors of the sense faculties,

original: guttadvārā pubbarattāpararattaṁ jāgariyānuyogamanuyuttā vipassakā kusalesu dhammesu
analyzed: gutta dvārā pubbaratta apararattam jāgariya anuyogam anuyuttāḥ vipassakā kusalesu dhammesu
translated: will be devoted to waking watch, will be contemplatives who will penetrate skillfully,

original: sagāravā ca sabrahmacārīsu theresu navesu majjhimesūti ayaṁ ettha bhagavato adhippāyo.🔽“Appamādo amatapadaṁ,
analyzed: ca sabrahmacārīsu theresu navesu majjhimesu iti ayam ettha bhagavataḥ adhippāyaḥ  appamādaḥ amata pada
translated: and will be respectful to their companions in the holy life, whether senior, newly ordained, or of middle standing.🔽“Carefulness is the deathless state;
Negligence is the state of the death.
The heedful do not die;
Those who are heedless are as if dead.”
What is the Blessed Lord’s intention here?

original: Ye amatapariyesanaṁ pariyesitukāmā bhavissanti, te appamattā viharissantīti ayaṁ ettha bhagavato adhippāyo.
analyzed: ye amata pariyesanam pariyesitu kāmāḥ bhavissanti te appamattāḥ viharissanti iti ayam ettha bhagavataḥ adhippāyaḥ
translated: Those who wish to seek the Deathless will do so heedfully. This is the Blessed Lord’s intention.
This is the intention.
Herein, what is the source?

original: Yathā so dhaniyo gopālako bhagavantaṁ āha—
analyzed: yathā saḥ dhaniyaḥ gopālakaḥ bhagavantam āha
translated: As the rich cowherd Nanda said to the Blessed Lord:
“The man who has sons delights in his sons,
The cowherd delights in his cows, indeed.
For man’s delight is in the fetter,

original: Na hi so nandati yo nirūpadhī”ti.
analyzed: na hi saḥ nandati yaḥ nirūpadhī iti
translated: He who is free from fetters has no delight.”
The Blessed Lord said:
“The man who has sons grieves for his sons,
The cowherd grieves for his cows, indeed.
For man’s grief is in the fetter,

original: Na hi so socati yo nirūpadhī”ti.
analyzed: na hi saḥ socati yaḥ nirūpadhī iti
translated: He who is free from fetters has no grief.”

original: Iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evaṁ ñāyati “idha bhagavā bāhiraṁ pariggahaṁ upadhiṁ āhā”ti.
analyzed: iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evam ñāyati idha bhagavā bāhiram pariggaham upadhim āha ati
translated: From this source, from this reason, it is known that here the Blessed Lord spoke of the external acquisition as a fetter.

original: Yathā ca māro pāpimā gijjhakūṭā pabbatā puthusilaṁ pātesi, bhagavā āha—🔽“Sacepi kevalaṁ sabbaṁ,
analyzed: yathā ca māraḥ pāpimā gijjhakūṭā pabbatā puthusilam pātesi bhagavā āha  sace pi kevalam
translated: And as Mara the Evil One threw a rock down from the Gijjhakuta mountain at the venerable Maha Kaccana, the Blessed Lord said:
“Even if you could make the whole of this Gijjhakuta mountain move,
The Buddhas, who are rightly freed,
Have no such stirring in their hearts.
The sky might fall, the earth might move,

original: Sabbeva pāṇā uda santaseyyuṁ;🔽Sallampi ce urasi pakappayeyyuṁ,
analyzed: sabbe iva pāṇāḥ uda santaseyyu  ce urasi pakappayeyyu
translated: All living things might lose their lives,🔽And yet the Buddhas would not fear,

original: Upadhīsu tāṇaṁ na karonti buddhā”ti.🔽Iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evaṁ ñāyati “idha bhagavā kāyaṁ upadhiṁ āhā”ti.
analyzed: upadhīsu tāṇam na karonti buddha ati  iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evam ñāyati idha bhagavā kāyam upadhim āha ati
translated: For they have no concern for self.🔽This is the reason, this is the cause why it is known that the Blessed One has abandoned the body as a possession.
And again, the Blessed One has said:

analyzed: na tam daḷham bandhanam āhu dhīrā  yat āyasam dāru ja pabbajam ca
translated: “The wise do not call that a strong bond🔽Which is made of iron, wood, or rope;
But the longing for jewels, earrings,

original: Puttesu dāresu ca yā apekkhā”ti.🔽Iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evaṁ ñāyati “idha bhagavā bāhiresu vatthūsu taṇhaṁ āhā”ti.
analyzed: puttesu dāresu ca yāḥ apekkhāti  iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evam ñāyati idha bhagavā bāhiresu vatthūsu taṇham āha ati
translated: And for sons and wives they call a strong bond.”🔽This is the reason, this is the cause why it is known that the Blessed One has abandoned craving for external things.
And again, the Blessed One has said:
“The wise call that a strong bond
Which is deep, loose, and hard to see;
But having cut this off, they wander about
Without concern for sensual pleasures.”

original: Iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evaṁ ñāyati “idha bhagavā bāhiravatthukāya taṇhāya pahānaṁ āhā”ti.
analyzed: iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evam ñāyati idha bhagavā bāhira vatthukāya taṇhāya pahānam āha ati
translated: From this source, from this cause, it is known that the Blessed One has taught the abandoning of craving with external things as its source.
And as he said:
“The sick, the impure, the rotten,
The foul-smelling, the body-bound,
The dripping, day and night,
Are the delight of fools.”

original: Iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evaṁ ñāyati “idha bhagavā ajjhattikavatthukāya taṇhāya pahānaṁ āhā”ti.
analyzed: iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evam ñāyati idha bhagavā ajjhattika vatthukāya taṇhāya pahānam āha ati
translated: From this source, from this cause, it is known that the Blessed One has taught the abandoning of craving with internal things as its source.
And as he said:
“Cut off the thread of your affection,
As one would a lotus stalk with a knife;
Make the path to peace your own,
Nibbana, taught by the One of Good Guidance.”

original: Iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evaṁ ñāyati “idha bhagavā ajjhattikavatthukāya taṇhāya pahānaṁ āhā”ti.
analyzed: iminā vatthunā iminā nidānena evam ñāyati idha bhagavā ajjhattika vatthukāya taṇhāya pahānam āha ati
translated: From this source, from this cause, it is known that the Blessed One has taught the abandoning of craving with internal things as its source.
This is the source.
Herein, what is the continuity of sequence?
As he said:
“Blind with passion, veiled in the net,
Covered by the lid of craving,
Bound by the fetter of heedlessness,
Like fish in a trap,
They come under the sway of old age and death.
like a calf for its mother’s udder” .
This is called craving for sense desires.
With what is it connected in the first and last place?
As it is said:
“The lustful man does not know the good,
The lustful man does not see the good.
Then there is darkness, blindness, and gloom,
When lust overpowers a man” .

original: Iti andhatāya ca sañchannatāya ca sāyeva taṇhā abhilapitā.
analyzed: iti andha tāya ca sañchanna tāya ca sāyā iva taṇhā abhilapitā
translated: So this craving is called “blind” and “covered” .

analyzed: yat ca āha kāmandhā jāla sañchannā taṇhā chadana chāditā ati
translated: And when it is said “blinded by lust, covered by a net” ,

original: Yañcāha ratto atthaṁ na jānāti, ratto dhammaṁ na passatīti, imehi padehi pariyuṭṭhānehi sāyeva taṇhā abhilapitā.
analyzed: yat ca āha rattaḥ attham na jānāti rattaḥ dhammam na passati iti imehi padehi pariyuṭṭhānehi sāyā iva taṇhā abhilapitā
translated: and “The lustful man does not know the good, the lustful man does not see the good” , this craving is called “covered” by these terms.

original: Yaṁ andhakāraṁ, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo, yā ca taṇhā ponobhavikā, yañcāha kāmāti ime kilesakāmā.
analyzed: yam andhakāra ayam dukkha samudayaḥ yā ca taṇhā ponobhavikā yañca āha kāma ati ime kilesa kāmā
translated: The darkness is the origin of suffering, and the craving that leads to further becoming is called “lust” .

original: Yañcāha jālasañchannāti tesaṁyeva kāmānaṁ payogena pariyuṭṭhānaṁ dasseti, tasmā kilesavasena ca pariyuṭṭhānavasena ca taṇhābandhanaṁ vuttaṁ.
analyzed: yat ca āha jāla sañchannā iti kāmānam payogena pariyuṭṭhānam dasseti tasmā kilesa vasena ca pariyuṭṭhāna vasena ca taṇhā bandhanam vutta
translated: And when it is said “covered by a net” , he shows the covering by the means of those lusts. Therefore the bondage of craving is stated by way of defilement and by way of covering.

original: Ye edisikā, te jarāmaraṇaṁ anventi, ayaṁ bhagavatā yathānikkhittagāthābalena dassitā jarāmaraṇamanventīti.
analyzed: ye edisikā te jarā maraṇam anventi ayam bhagavatā yathā nikkhitta gāthā balena dassitāḥ jarā maraṇam anventi iti
translated: Those who are like this are subject to aging-and-death. This is how the Exalted One shows by the power of the verse as it stands that those who are subject to aging-and-death are subject to the other states of the dependent origination.

original: “Yassa papañcā ṭhitī ca natthi,🔽Sandānaṁ palighañca vītivatto;
analyzed: yassa papañcā ṭhitī ca natthi  sandānam palighan ca vītivattaḥ
translated: “He who has no proliferation and no settled view,🔽Who has gone beyond the yoke and the fetter,
The sage who wanders free from craving—
The world with its gods does not know him” .

original: Papañcā nāma taṇhādiṭṭhimānā, tadabhisaṅkhatā ca saṅkhārā.🔽Ṭhiti nāma anusayā.
analyzed: papañcā nāma taṇhā diṭṭhi mānā tad abhisaṅkhatā ca saṅkhārā  ṭhiti nāma anusayā
translated: “Proliferation” is craving, views, and conceit, and the formations that are determined by them.🔽“Settled view” is the latent tendencies.

original: Sandānaṁ nāma taṇhāya pariyuṭṭhānaṁ, yāni chattiṁsataṇhāya jāliniyā vicaritāni.
analyzed: sandānam nāma taṇhāya pariyuṭṭhāna yāni chattisa taṇhāya jāliniyā vicaritāni
translated: “Yoke” is the obsession of craving, which is the thirty-six modes of craving.

original: Paligho nāma moho.🔽Ye ca papañcā saṅkhārā yā ca ṭhiti yaṁ sandānañca yaṁ palighañca yo etaṁ sabbaṁ samatikkanto, ayaṁ vuccati nittaṇho iti.
analyzed: palighaḥ nāma mohaḥ 🔽ye ca papañcā saṅkhārāḥ yā ca ṭhiti yam sandānam ca yam paligham ca yaḥ etam sabbam samatikkantaḥ ayam vuccati nittaṇhaḥ iti
translated: “Fetter” is delusion.🔽“He who has gone beyond all this” is called “free from craving.”

original: Tattha pariyuṭṭhānasaṅkhārā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyā vā upapajjavedanīyā vā aparāpariyavedanīyā vā, evaṁ taṇhā tividhaṁ phalaṁ deti diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajje vā apare vā pariyāye.
analyzed: tattha pariyuṭṭhāna saṅkhārāḥ diṭṭha dhamma vedanīyāḥ vā upapajja vedanīyāḥ vā apara apariya vedanīyāḥ vā evam taṇhā tividham phalam deti diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajje vā apare vā pariyāye
translated: Herein, the determinations that are determinations of craving give a threefold fruit: they give their fruit in the here-and-now or in the next existence or in some subsequent existence.
So the Blessed One said:

original: “yaṁ lobhapakataṁ kammaṁ karoti kāyena vā vācāya vā manasā vā, tassa vipākaṁ anubhoti diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajje vā apare vā pariyāye”ti.
analyzed: yam lobha pakatam kammam karoti kāyena vā vācāya vā manasā vā tassa vipākam anubhoti diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajje vā apare vā pariyāyeti
translated: “Any action that is done by body, speech, or mind out of greed has suffering as its outcome, whether it be in the here-and-now or in the next existence or in some subsequent existence” .

original: Idaṁ bhagavato pubbāparena yujjati.🔽Tattha pariyuṭṭhānaṁ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ vā kammaṁ upapajjavedanīyaṁ vā kammaṁ🔽aparāpariyāyavedanīyaṁ vā kammaṁ, evaṁ kammaṁ tidhā vipaccati diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajje
analyzed: idam bhagavataḥ pubba aparena yujjati  tattha pariyuṭṭhānam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam vā kammam upapajja vedanīyam vā kamma  apara apariyāya vedanīyam vā kamma evam kammam tidhā vipaccati diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajje
translated: This is the Blessed One’s statement that fits in with the forward order.🔽Herein, the determinations that are determinations of craving are either kamma that gives result in the here-and-now or kamma that gives result in the next existence or kamma that gives result in some subsequent existence.
So kamma gives its result in three ways: it gives its result in the here-and-now or in the next existence or in some subsequent existence.
As it is said:

analyzed: yat ce bālaḥ idha pāṇa atipātī hoti pe
translated: “Whatever a fool undertakes here By way of action, speech, or thought, Out of greed, hatred, or delusion, That is said to be action that is unprofitable” .

original: micchādiṭṭhi hoti, tassa diṭṭhe vā dhamme vipākaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti upapajje vā apare vā pariyāye”ti.
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhi hoti tassa diṭṭhe vā dhamme vipākam paṭisavedeti upapajje vā apare vā pariyāyeti
translated: He experiences the result either here and now or in some future existence.”
This is the Blessed Lord’s statement that is consistent in both parts.

original: Tattha pariyuṭṭhānaṁ paṭisaṅkhānabalena pahātabbaṁ, saṅkhārā dassanabalena, chattiṁsa taṇhāvicaritāni bhāvanābalena pahātabbānīti evaṁ taṇhāpi tidhā pahīyati.🔽Yā nittaṇhātā ayaṁ saupādisesā nibbānadhātu.
analyzed: tattha pariyuṭṭhānam paṭisaṅkhāna balena saṅkhārāḥ dassana balena chattisa taṇhā vicaritāni bhāvanā balena pahātabbāni iti evam taṇhā api tidhā pahīyati  yā nittaṇhā tā ayam sa aupādisesā nibbāna dhātu
translated: Herein, obsession is to be abandoned by the power of reflection, determinations by the power of seeing, and the thirty-six modes of behaviour of craving by the power of development. So craving is abandoned in three ways.🔽The state of being without craving is the extinction element with trace left.

analyzed: bhedā kāyassa ayam anupādisesā nibbāna dhātu
translated: The state of being without craving and without trace left is the extinction element without trace left.
“Expansion” is said to be the following.

original: Yañcāha bhagavā “papañceti atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ cakkhuviññeyyaṁ rūpaṁ ārabbhā”ti.
analyzed: yat ca āha bhagavā papañceti atīta anāgata paccuppannam cakkhu viññeyyam rūpam ārabbha ati
translated: And the Blessed Lord said: “He expands with regard to visible objects cognizable by the eye that have been, or will be, seen” .
And the Blessed Lord said:

original: “atīte, rādha, rūpe anapekkho hohi, anāgataṁ rūpaṁ mā abhinandi, paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭinissaggāya paṭipajjā”ti.
analyzed: atīte rādha rūpe anapekkhaḥ hohi anāgatam rūpam mā abhinandi paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭinissaggāya paṭipajjāti
translated: “Rādha, be unattracted, Rādha, do not be attracted;
This is the Blessed Lord’s statement that is consistent in both parts.

original: Yo cāpi papañco ye ca saṅkhārā yā ca atītānāgatapaccuppannassa abhinandanā, idaṁ ekatthaṁ.
analyzed: yaḥ ca api papañcaḥ ye ca saṅkhārāḥ yā ca atīta anāgata paccuppannassa abhinandanā idam ekattha
translated: And the proliferation and the determinations and the delighting in the past, future, and present are one in meaning.

original: Api ca aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi akkharehi aññamaññehi byañjanehi aparimāṇā dhammadesanā vuttā bhagavatā.
analyzed: api ca aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi akkharehi aññamaññehi byañjanehi aparimāṇā dhamma desanā vuttā bhagavatā
translated: And besides, the Blessed One has spoken of the Teaching in countless ways with different terms, phrases, and syllables.

original: Evaṁ suttena suttaṁ saṁsandayitvā pubbāparena saddhiṁ yojayitvā suttaṁ niddiṭṭhaṁ bhavati.
analyzed: evam suttena suttam sasandayitvā pubba aparena saddhim yojayitvā suttam niddiṭṭham bhavati
translated: So the Thread is demonstrated by combining one Thread with another and by correlating the earlier with the later.

original: So cāyaṁ pubbāparo sandhi catubbidho atthasandhi byañjanasandhi desanāsandhi niddesasandhīti.
analyzed: so ca ayam pubba aparaḥ sandhi catubbidhaḥ attha sandhi byañjana sandhi desanā sandhi niddesa sandhi iti
translated: And this correlation of the earlier with the later is fourfold: correlation of meaning, correlation of phrasing, correlation of teaching, and correlation of demonstration.

original: Tattha atthasandhi chappadāni saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammatā paññattīti.🔽Byañjanasandhi chappadāni akkharaṁ padaṁ byañjanaṁ ākāro nirutti niddesoti.
analyzed: tattha atthasandhi chappadāni saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkamma tā paññatti iti  byañjana sandhi chappadāni akkharam padam byañjanam ākāraḥ nirutti niddesaḥ ti
translated: Herein, correlation of meaning is six terms: 1. urging, 2. showing, 3. revealing, 4. analysing, 5. exhibiting, 6. defining.🔽Correlation of phrasing is six terms: 1. syllable, 2. word, 3. phrase, 4. mode, 5. voice, 6. demonstration.

original: Desanāsandhi na ca pathaviṁ nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca.
analyzed: desanā sandhi na ca pathavim nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca
translated: Correlation of teaching is six terms: 1. not, 2. not-yet, 3. not-next, 4. not-last, 5. not-both, 6. not-in-between.

original: Na ca āpaṁ nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca, na ca tejaṁ nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati🔽ca, na ca vāyuṁ nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca …pe… na ca ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ nissāya🔽… na ca viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ nissāya … na ca ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ nissāya … na ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ🔽nissāya … na ca imaṁ lokaṁ nissāya … na ca paralokaṁ nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca.
analyzed: na ca āpam nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca na ca tejam nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati  ca na ca vāyum nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca pe na ca ākāsānañcāyatanam nissāya  na ca viññāṇañca āyatanam nissāya na ca ākiñcañña āyatanam nissāya  / nissāya na ca imam lokam nissāya na ca para lokam nissāya jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca
translated: He does not meditate depending on water … depending on fire … depending on air … depending on the base of infinite space … depending on the base of infinite consciousness … depending on the base of nothingness … depending on the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception … depending on this world … depending on the other world.

original: Yamidaṁ ubhayamantarena diṭṭhaṁ sutaṁ mutaṁ viññātaṁ pattaṁ pariyesitaṁ vitakkitaṁ vicāritaṁ manasānucintitaṁ, tampi nissāya na jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca.
analyzed: yam idam ubhayam antarena diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam pattam pariyesitam vitakkitam vicāritam manasā anucintita tam pi nissāya na jhāyati jhāyī jhāyati ca
translated: He does not meditate depending on anything seen, heard, sensed, or cognized, on anything obtained, sought after, or pondered by the mind, or on anything considered internally or externally.🔽He does not meditate depending on anything at all.

original: Ayaṁ sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anissitena cittena na ñāyati jhāyanto.
analyzed: ayam sa devake loke sa mārake sa brahmake sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāya sa deva manussāya anissitena cittena na ñāyati jhāyantaḥ
translated: He is not known to be meditating in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

original: Yathā māro pāpimā godhikassa kulaputtassa viññāṇaṁ samanvesanto na jānāti na passati.
analyzed: yathā māraḥ pāpimā godhikassa kula puttassa viññāṇam samanvesantaḥ na jānāti na passati
translated: As Mara, the Evil One, did not know or see the consciousness of the clansman Godhika when he was searching for it.

original: So hi papañcātīto taṇhāpahānena diṭṭhinissayopissa natthi.
analyzed: so hi papañca atītaḥ taṇhā apahānena diṭṭhi nissayo pissa natthi
translated: For he had gone beyond the proliferation of the world and had no dependence on views through the abandoning of craving.

original: Yathā ca godhikassa, evaṁ vakkalissa sadevakena lokena samārakena sabrahmakena sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anissitacittā na ñāyanti jhāyamānā.
analyzed: yathā ca godhikassa evam vakkalissa sa devakena lokena sa mārakena sa brahmakena sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāya sa deva manussāya a nissita cittāḥ na ñāyanti jhāyamānāḥ
translated: And just as with Godhika, so also with Vakkali, his mind was not known by the world with its gods, its Maras, and its Brahmas, with its recluses and brahmans, by its generations of nobles, brahmans, and householders, as he was burning up.
This is the Thread’s Teaching-Sign.

original: Tattha katamā niddesasandhi?🔽Nissitacittā akusalapakkhena niddisitabbā, anissitacittā kusalapakkhena niddisitabbā.🔽Nissitacittā kilesena niddisitabbā, anissitacittā vodānena niddisitabbā.
analyzed: tattha katamā  nissita cittā akusala pakkhena niddisitabbā anissita cittā kusala pakkhena niddisitabbā  nissita cittā kilesena niddisitabbā anissita cittā vodānena niddisitabbā
translated: Herein, what is the Thread’s Mode of Conveying a Teaching?🔽“ With a mind dependent “ is demonstrated by the unprofitable side, and “ with a mind independent “ is demonstrated by the profitable side.🔽“ With a mind dependent “ is demonstrated by defilement, and “ with a mind independent “ is demonstrated by cleansing.

original: Nissitacittā saṁsārappavattiyā niddisitabbā, anissitacittā saṁsāranivattiyā niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā sa sāra ppavattiyā niddisitabbā anissita cittā sa sāra nivattiyā niddisitabbā
translated: “ With a mind dependent “ is demonstrated by the occurrence of the round of rebirths, and “ with a mind independent “ is demonstrated by the cessation of the round of rebirths.

original: Nissitacittā taṇhāya ca avijjāya ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā samathena ca vipassanāya ca niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā taṇhāya ca avijjāya ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā samathena ca vipassanāya ca niddisitabbā
translated: Those with a mind that is dependent should be shown up by craving and ignorance. Those with a mind that is independent should be shown up by serenity and insight.

original: Nissitacittā ahirikena ca anottappena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā hiriyā ca ottappena ca niddisitabbā.🔽Nissitacittā asatiyā ca asampajaññena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā satiyā ca sampajaññena ca niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā ahirikena ca anottappena ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā hiriyā ca ottappena ca niddisitabbā  nissita cittā asatiyā ca asampajaññena ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā satiyā ca sampajaññena ca niddisitabbā
translated: Those with a mind that is dependent should be shown up by lack of shame and lack of fear of wrongdoing. Those with a mind that is independent should be shown up by shame and fear of wrongdoing.🔽Those with a mind that is dependent should be shown up by lack of mindfulness and lack of full awareness. Those with a mind that is independent should be shown up by mindfulness and full awareness.

original: Nissitacittā ayoniyā ca ayonisomanasikārena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā yoniyā ca yonisomanasikārena ca niddisitabbā.🔽Nissitacittā kosajjena ca dovacassena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā vīriyārambhena ca sovacassena ca niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā a yoniyā ca a yoni somanasikārena ca niddisitabbā a nissita cittā yoniyā ca yoni somanasikārena ca niddisitabbā  nissita cittā kosajjena ca dovacassena ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā vīriya ārambhena ca sovacassena ca niddisitabbā
translated: Those with a mind that is dependent should be shown up by wrong method and wrong attention. Those with a mind that is independent should be shown up by right method and right attention.🔽Those with a mind that is dependent should be shown up by laziness and unruliness. Those with a mind that is independent should be shown up by the arousing of energy and being easy to admonish.

original: Nissitacittā assaddhiyena ca pamādena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā saddhāya ca appamādena ca niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā assaddhiyena ca pamādena ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā saddhāya ca appamādena ca niddisitabbā
translated: Those with a mind that is dependent should be shown up by lack of faith and laziness. Those with a mind that is independent should be shown up by faith and diligence.

original: Nissitacittā asaddhammassavanena ca asaṁvaraṇena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā saddhammassavanena ca saṁvarena ca niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā asaddhamma ssavanena ca a savaraṇena ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā saddhamma ssavanena ca savarena ca niddisitabbā
translated: and by the listening to the True Idea and by restraint.

original: Nissitacittā abhijjhāya ca byāpādena ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā anabhijjhāya ca abyāpādena ca niddisitabbā.🔽Nissitacittā nīvaraṇehi ca saṁyojaniyehi ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā rāgavirāgāya ca cetovimuttiyā avijjāvirāgāya ca paññāvimuttiyā niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā abhijjhāya ca byāpādena ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā anabhijjhāya ca a byāpādena ca niddisitabbā  nissita cittā nīvaraṇehi ca sayojaniyehi ca niddisitabbā a nissita cittā rāga virāgāya ca cetaḥ vimuttiyā avijjā virāgāya ca paññā vimuttiyā niddisitabbā
translated: and by covetousness and by ill will.🔽and by the hindrances and by the fetters.🔽and by the fading of lust and by the fading of ignorance, and by the liberation of will and by the liberation by understanding.

original: Nissitacittā ucchedadiṭṭhiyā ca sassatadiṭṭhiyā ca niddisitabbā, anissitacittā saupādisesāya ca anupādisesāya ca nibbānadhātuyā niddisitabbā.
analyzed: nissita cittā uccheda diṭṭhiyā ca sassata diṭṭhiyā ca niddisitabbā anissita cittā sa aupādisesāya ca anupādisesāya ca nibbāna dhātuyā niddisitabbā
translated: and by the annihilation view and by the eternity view.
This is the Thread’s Mode of Conveying a Teaching.
Hence the venerable Maha Kaccana said: “The Mode of Conveying a Teaching is the highest Thread” .
The Mode of Conveying an Analysis is fourfold.
